facts.text: Compromise decree passed on 24-6-1959 in appeal from decree in O.S. 85 of 1949-50. Defendant agrees to receive from plaintiff a lakh of rupees as consideration for sale of property No. 44, Mahatma Gandhi Road, Bangalore, together with stamp charges of Rs. 3,300/- with interest at six per cent per annum from 16-3-1947, together with Rs. 7,000/- deducted by the Corporation minus rent received Rs. 22,500/- and give up all rights to the said property. Plaintiff entitled to materials on premises.

Period fixed for payment by plaintiff to defendant till 1-1-1960. Plaintiff to deposit amount in court for payment to defendant. On failure to deposit by 1-1-1960, suit in appeal dismissed with costs throughout. Time essence of contract, no further extension, dismissal automatic.

Respondent applied for challan on 22-12-1959, challan issued on 24-12-1959 (last working day before court closed for Christmas holidays). December 31, 1959 and January 1, 1960 were holidays; neither courts nor banks open.
Respondent filed execution case No.25/1960 to compel appellant to execute conveyance.
Appellant filed execution case No. 45 of 1960 for costs on basis suit dismissed per decree.
District Court, Bangalore held deposit in substantial compliance, allowed Ex. 25/1960, dismissed Ex. 45/1960.
Appellant filed Ex. Regular Appeals Nos. 33-34 of 1961 before Mysore High Court.
Mysore High Court Division Bench dismissed appeals with costs on 16-6-1966.
No evidence parties knew at compromise time that 31-12-1959 and 1-1-1960 would be holidays.

legal_issues.text: Whether the deposit made by the respondent on 2-1-1960 was within the time specified in the compromise decree and would enable him to compel the appellant to execute the sale deed.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent had practically six months to deposit, should have deposited earlier, not wait till last day; if last day holiday, must suffer consequences.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Distinction between act on certain day (lex non cogit ad impossibilia applies) vs within period (law takes no notice of impossibility on last day)

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent could have paid amount directly to appellant on 31-12-1959 or 1-1-1960 under Order XXI Rule 1, instead of waiting to deposit in court.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Order XXI Rule 1; Kunj Bihari v. Bindeshri Prasad (ILR Vol. 51, 1929 Allahabad 527), Roshan Lal v. Ganpat Lal (AIR 1938 All 199), Indal v. Chaudhary Ram Nidh (AIR 1946 Oudh 156), Ram Kinkar Singh v. Smt. Kamal Basini Devi (AIR 1938 Patna 451)

petitioner_arguments.text: Execution court cannot alter or modify decree terms; automatic dismissal on default per clause; deposit on 2-1-1960 not compliance.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Court executing decree must execute as it stands

petitioner_arguments.text: Compromise decree is a contract; party bound absolutely notwithstanding impossibility.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Halsbury's Laws of England Vol. XIV, p.622 para 151; Wentworth v. Bullen

respondent_arguments.text: Deposit on 2-1-1960 in substantial compliance as court closed on 1-1-1960.

court_reasoning.text: Respondent had liberty to deposit till including 1-1-1960; general rule act may be done up to last moment of last day; not choosing earlier does not affect right on last day.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Halsbury's Laws of England vol. 37, 3rd Edn, p.96

court_reasoning.text: Rejects distinction argument; cites Fateh Khan v. Chhajju (AIR 1931 Lahore 386) where similar argument rejected for pre-emptor deposit on reopening day.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accepting argument curtails days allowed by decree without reason

court_reasoning.text: Direct payment option under O XXI R1 not applicable; decree specifically requires deposit in court, no option; appellant could refuse tender.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishes Kunj Bihari etc.; cites Chatlapali Suryaprakasa Rao v. Polisetti Venkataratnam (AIR 1938 Madras 523), Premchand Bhikabhai v. Ramdeo Sukdeo Marwadi (AIR 1949 Nagpur 141)

court_reasoning.text: Principle: parties prevented by court closure (not own act) entitled to do act at first subsequent opportunity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Muhammad Jan v. Chiam Lal (ILR All XLVI 1924 p.328); Shooshee Bhusan Rudro v. Gobind Chunder Roy (ILR Cal XVIII 1891 p.231); Sambasiva Chari v. Ramasami Reddi (ILR 22 Mad 1899 p.179); Fateh Khan; Mayor v. Harding (1867 2 QB 410); Halsbury vol.37 p.97 para 172

court_reasoning.text: Execution court construed decree in light of law, found deposit compliant; not varying decree.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Court executes decree as stands after considering law

court_reasoning.text: Compromise decree more than contract; effective as court order unless set aside.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Charles Hubert Kinch v. Edward Keith Walcott (AIR 1929 PC 289); Govind Waman v. Murlidhar Shrinivas (AIR 1953 Bom 412); Morris v. Barret (English LR 141 p.768)

holdings.text: Deposit on 2-1-1960 in substance and effect a deposit in terms of compromise decree due to court closure on 1-1-1960.

precedents_cited.relevance: Pre-emptor deposit on reopening day after last day holiday held in time; rejected 'should have deposited earlier' argument
Judgment debtor with option to pay direct or court cannot claim holiday extension if chooses court deposit
Similar to Kunj Bihari on option to pay direct

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Kinkar Singh v. Smt. Kamal Basini Devi
Chatlapali Suryaprakasa Rao v. Polisetti Venkataratnam
precedents_cited.relevance: Instalment deposit next day after holiday held in time even if decree silent on payee

precedents_cited.case_name: Premchand Bhikabhai v. Ramdeo Sukdeo Marwadi
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar to Chatlapali on instalment deposit

precedents_cited.citation: ILR Allahabad Series, Vol. XLVI, 1924, p. 328
precedents_cited.relevance: Pre-emption deposit on reopening after vacation held in time; principle of court closure allows next opportunity

precedents_cited.case_name: Shooshee Bhusan Rudro v. Gobind Chunder Roy
precedents_cited.relevance: Delay by court closure entitles act on first opening day
Principle of court closure allows next opportunity
Transmission on next day after holidays held compliance despite 3-day limit

precedents_cited.case_name: Charles Hubert Kinch v. Edward Keith Walcott
precedents_cited.relevance: Consent order effective as court order unless discharged
Consent decree not mere contract; binding despite unlawful terms unless set aside
Consent order payment on next day after Sunday held timely; not governed purely by contract principles
Contract embodied in judge's order still subject to contract incidents but more

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Option for judgment debtor to pay direct to decree holder or deposit in court; distinguished as decree mandates court deposit

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned in Govind Waman; consent decree term contrary not nullity

statutes_cited.name: Sunday Observance Act, 1677
statutes_cited.relevance: Exception where act prohibited on Sunday

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, holding that the deposit on 2-1-1960 was in substance and effect within the terms of the compromise decree due to court holidays on 31-12-1959 and 1-1-1960, upholding the High Court and District Court orders allowing respondent's execution and dismissing appellant's.
outcome.relief_granted: Respondent entitled to enforce compromise decree; appellant to execute sale deed.
outcome.costs: High Court dismissed appeals with costs; SC outcome aligns

key_quotes.text: "the deposit made by the respondent on 2-1-1960 was in substance and in effect a deposit made in terms of the compromise decree"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on timeliness of deposit

key_quotes.text: "there is a generally recognised principle of law under which parties who are prevented from doing a thing in court on a particular day, not by an act of their own but by the court itself, are entitled to do it at the first subsequent opportunity."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A consent order, not discharged by mutual agreement and remaining unreduced is as effective as an order of the court made otherwise than by consent"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Status of compromise decree superior to mere contract
